definition: 15 or 16-digit unique identifier for a payment card account assigned by the card issuer.
official_pci_description: The Primary Account Number (PAN) is the principal account number identifying the cardholder account. Per PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.5, PANs must be rendered unreadable at all points where stored through one of four methods: (1) encryption of stored PAN using strong cryptography; (2) tokenization of PAN; (3) truncation of PAN; (4) hash-based mechanism using strong cryptography. PANs must be masked in display (show first 6 and last 4 digits only).
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.5: Render PAN Unreadable

definition: The full name of the individual to whom the payment card is issued, as printed on the card.
official_pci_description: Cardholder name is account data constituting Cardholder Data (CHD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1. Must be protected per Requirement 3 with appropriate encryption when stored. Subject to access restrictions (Requirement 7) and audit logging (Requirement 10). Must be deleted according to documented data retention policies. Retention period must be based on business need with documented justification.
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3: Protect Stored Cardholder Data

definition: The month and year (MM/YY format) indicating when the payment card expires and is no longer valid for transactions.
official_pci_description: Card expiration date is account data constituting Cardholder Data (CHD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1. Must be protected per Requirement 3 if stored. Subject to data minimization principle - storage only if business justified. Must be encrypted if stored. Subject to documented retention policies with secure deletion upon retention period expiration.
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3: Protect Stored Cardholder Data

definition: Three-digit code encoded on the magnetic stripe (or embedded in chip) that provides information about card usage limitations and transaction requirements. Also called CVC1 (Card Verification Code 1).
official_pci_description: Service Code is account data constituting Cardholder Data (CHD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1. Provides information about cardholder authorization and usage limitations. Must be protected per Requirement 3 if stored. Subject to encryption requirement (AES-256 minimum) if retained. Storage justified only by business need. Retention period documented with secure deletion.
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3: Protect Stored Cardholder Data

data_element: Full Track Data / Magnetic Stripe Data
definition: Complete data from the magnetic stripe or chip equivalent, including all encoded information (Track 1 and Track 2) used during transaction authorization.
official_pci_description: Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2. Full track data contains all magnetic stripe data encoded on the card. PCI DSS v4.0.1 explicitly prohibits storage of SAD after transaction authorization under ANY circumstances, including encrypted form. Only exception: Card issuers with documented, legitimate business need (per Requirement 3.3). Violation of this requirement is critical compliance failure.
deletion_requirement: MUST DELETE immediately after transaction authorization
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2: Sensitive Authentication Data Cannot Be Stored After Authorization

definition: 3 or 4-digit security code on card (varies by card brand) used to verify cardholder identity during transactions. Visa: CVV2 (back); Mastercard: CVC2 (back); Amex: CID (front).
official_pci_description: Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2. Card Verification Code (CVV, CVV2, CVC2, CID depending on brand) is authentication credential that cannot be stored after authorization. Absolute prohibition - no exceptions except issuers with documented need. Even encrypted storage is violation. Must be deleted in real-time after authorization is obtained. Storage violates PCI DSS Requirement 3.2.
deletion_requirement: MUST DELETE immediately after transaction authorization
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2: Sensitive Authentication Data Cannot Be Stored After Authorization

definition: Personal Identification Number (PIN) or PIN Block used for cardholder authentication, particularly for ATM and debit transactions. PIN Block is encrypted PIN for transmission.
official_pci_description: Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirements 3.2 and 3.3. PIN and PIN block data cannot be stored after transaction authorization under normal circumstances. Limited exception only for card issuers with explicit, documented business justification (Requirement 3.3). Storage of PIN/PIN blocks by merchants or service providers violates requirement. Must be deleted immediately upon authorization completion.
deletion_requirement: MUST DELETE immediately after transaction authorization
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2 & 3.3: SAD Cannot Be Stored

definition: Cryptographic key used by card issuers and processors to activate and personalize newly issued payment cards.
official_pci_description: Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD) per PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2. Card Activation Keys are cryptographic credentials used in card activation and personalization process. Cannot be stored after transaction/use completion. Absolute prohibition on storage. Used only by card issuers and payment processors. Must be deleted upon completion of activation process.
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 3.2: Sensitive Authentication Data Cannot Be Stored

definition: Collective term for both Cardholder Data (CHD) and Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD) together. Refers to any data that could be used fraudulently to obtain, authorize, or use payment cards.
official_pci_description: Account Data is defined in PCI DSS v4.0.1 as either Cardholder Data or Sensitive Authentication Data. Cardholder Data (allowed with encryption): PAN, cardholder name, expiration date, service code. Sensitive Authentication Data (prohibited post-authorization): Full track data, CVV/CVV2/CVC2/CID, PIN/PIN blocks, CAK. Organizations must maintain policies defining what account data is stored, where, duration, and how it is destroyed. Account data inventory required.
storage_allowed: Depends on element (CHD: YES, SAD: NO post-auth)
encryption_required: Depends on element (CHD: YES, SAD: N/A)
deletion_requirement: Depends on element per retention policy

definition: Payment card information being transmitted between systems, networks, or organizations during payment processing authorization and settlement.
official_pci_description: Cardholder Data in transit must be protected per PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 4. All CHD transmitted over public networks must be encrypted using strong cryptography (TLS 1.2 or higher minimum). Point-to-Point Encryption (P2PE) may be used for in-store transactions. End-to-end encryption protects CHD from point of entry through processing. Encryption keys must be protected. No fallback to weak protocols allowed.
official_regulation_reference: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 4: Protect Cardholder Data with Strong Cryptography During Transmission
